{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person |name= Sir Robin Durnford-Slater |birth_date=9 July 1902 |death_date={{death-date and age|28 June 1984|19 July 1902}} |birth_place= India |death_place= Chichester, Sussex, England |birth_name=Leonard Francis Slater |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance= {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom]] |serviceyears= 1923–1961 |rank= [[Admiral (United Kingdom)|Admiral]] |commands=[[HMS Hermes (95)|HMS ''Hermes'']]
[[HMS Vernon (shore establishment)|HMS ''Vernon'']]
[[HMS Gambia (48)|HMS ''Gambia'']]
[[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore|Nore Command]] |branch=[[Image:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|23px]] [[Royal Navy]] |unit= |battles=[[World War II]]
[[Suez Crisis]] |awards= [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] |laterwork= }} [[Admiral (Royal Navy)|Admiral]] '''Sir Robin (Leonard Francis) Durnford-Slater''' [[Order of the Bath|KCB]] (9 July 1902 – 28 June 1984) was a [[Royal Navy]] officer who went on to be the last [[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore]]. ==Early life== Born as Leonard Francis Slater in 1902 in the Punjab area of [[British India|India]] the son of [[Leonard Slater]] an Army Captain and his wife Constance Durnford Slater. His younger brother [[John Durnford-Slater|John]] became notable as the first British Commando. ==Naval career== Durnford-Slater joined the [[Royal Navy]] in 1923.{{LondonGazette|issue=32855|supp=|startpage=5700|date=21 August 1923|accessdate=6 August 2010}} He served in [[World War II]], initially as Executive Officer on the aircraft carrier [[HMS Hermes (95)|HMS ''Hermes'']] which was sunk in 1942.[http://www.axfordsabode.org.uk/pdf-docs/hermes01.pdf HMS Hermes] He then joined the [[torpedo]] school [[HMS Vernon (shore establishment)|HMS ''Vernon'']].[http://www.kcl.ac.uk/lhcma/locreg/SLATER.shtml Liddell Hart Centre for Military Archives] He next became Senior Officer for the 42nd and the 7th Escort Group of [[Western Approaches Command]]. Later he became Training Captain on the staff of the Commander-in-Chief, Western Approaches Command and finally Director of Underwater Weapons at the [[Admiralty]]. After the War he became Senior Officer for 1st Escort Flotilla in the [[Eastern Fleet|Far East Fleet]]. He went on to be Commandant at the School of Amphibious Warfare and then Captain of the [[cruiser]] [[HMS Gambia (48)|HMS ''Gambia'']]. In 1953 he was made Deputy Controller of the Navy. He commanding the Naval Forces during [[Suez Crisis]] in 1956.[http://www.historynet.com/suez-crisis-operation-musketeer.htm/2 Suez Crisis: Operation Musketeer] After that he was made Flag Officer, Second in charge of the [[Mediterranean Fleet]] and then, from 1958, the last [[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore]]. He retired in 1961. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box | title=[[Commander-in-Chief, The Nore]] | years=1958–1961 | before=[[Frederick Parham|Sir Frederick Parham]] | after=Post Disbanded}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Durnford-Slater, Robin}} [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1984 deaths]] [[Category:Royal Navy admirals]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]]
